title: Jobs boom boosts NSW surplus to $1.2b
text:
A boost in payroll tax, caused by a drop in unemployment, has helped lift the NSW budget surplus to $1.2 billion, final figures to be released on Wednesday will show.

The state's final budget outcome for the previous financial year, 2018-19, shows the surplus is $417 million higher than the $802 million balance that was forecast in the June budget.

Dominic Perrottet says NSW's finances are in good shape. Louise Kennerley

NSW Treasurer Dominic Perrottet said $300 million of extra revenue would be put into the NSW Generations Fund – a sovereign wealth fund set up in 2018 to enable debt retirement and investment in special projects.

Mr Perrottet said the $417 million revenue boost since the budget was because of several factors, including an increase in payroll tax – a consequence of increased employment.

Unemployment in NSW was 4.3 per cent in August, well below the national average of 5.3 per cent.
description: A boost in payroll tax, helped by a drop in unemployment, has lifted the NSW budget surplus to $1.2 billion.
